question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Solve the inequality
\[\frac{(x - 2)(x - 3)(x - 4)}{(x - 1)(x - 5)(x - 6)} > 0.\]
inference:
The inequality is $\frac{(x - 2)(x - 3)(x - 4)}{(x - 1)(x - 5)(x - 6)} > 0$.
The critical values are $x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6$.
We analyze the sign of the expression for the intervals defined by these critical values.
\begin{itemize}
    \item $x < 1$: All factors are negative, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} > 0$.
    \item $1 < x < 2$: $(x-2)$ is negative, and other factors are positive, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} < 0$.
    \item $2 < x < 3$: $(x-2)$ is positive, $(x-3)$ is negative, and other factors are positive, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} < 0$.
    \item $3 < x < 4$: $(x-2)$, $(x-3)$ are positive, $(x-4)$ is negative, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} < 0$.
    \item $4 < x < 5$: $(x-2)$, $(x-3)$, $(x-4)$ are positive, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} > 0$.
    \item $5 < x < 6$: $(x-2)$, $(x-3)$, $(x-4)$, $(x-5)$ are positive, and $(x-6)$ is negative, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} < 0$.
    \item $x > 6$: All factors are positive, so $\frac{(x-2)(x-3)(x-4)}{(x-1)(x-5)(x-6)} > 0$.
\end{itemize}
The inequality is satisfied when $x < 1$ or $4 < x < 5$ or $x > 6$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{(-\infty, 1) \cup (4, 5) \cup (6, \infty)}$
ground_truth:
We can build a sign chart, but since all of the factors are linear, we can track what happens to the expression as $x$ increases.  At $x = 0,$ the expression is positive.  As $x$ increases past 1, the expression becomes negative.  As $x$ increases past 2, the expression becomes positive, and so on.  Thus, the solution is
\[x \in \boxed{(-\infty,1) \cup (2,3) \cup (4,5) \cup (6,\infty)}.\]
